name: I'm coming around to sticking with RDS, but maybe switching to PostgreSQL with its native JSON functionality. Still, I wish there was a simple JSON document database for AWS, which was backed by S3 storage, available as a service.

content.html: I'm coming around to sticking with RDS, but maybe switching to PostgreSQL with its native JSON functionality. Still, I wish there was a simple JSON document database for AWS, which was backed by S3 storage, available as a service.
content.value: I'm coming around to sticking with RDS, but maybe switching to PostgreSQL with its native JSON functionality. Still, I wish there was a simple JSON document database for AWS, which was backed by S3 storage, available as a service.

summary: Close, but not quite the right fit. S3 Select is more suited for searching within a single object. Athena is closer, but it’s interaction model is a little off, as it sends results of queries off to a bucket.

content.html: Close, but not quite the right fit. S3 Select is more suited for searching within a single object. Athena is closer, but it’s interaction model is a little off, as it sends results of queries off to a bucket.
content.value: Close, but not quite the right fit. S3 Select is more suited for searching within a single object. Athena is closer, but it’s interaction model is a little off, as it sends results of queries off to a bucket.

summary: What I really want is to be able to list objects in a bucket that match a set of object tags.

content.html: What I really want is to be able to list objects in a bucket that match a set of object tags.
content.value: What I really want is to be able to list objects in a bucket that match a set of object tags.

summary:
Have you tried Redshift Spectrum? You to query JSON data (and other formats) directly from S3 - no loading. Mix and match external S3 data with Redshift data. Performance is excellent.
Docs: docs.aws.amazon.com/redshift/lates…
Customer blog: aws.amazon.com/blogs/big-data…

content.html:
Have you tried Redshift Spectrum? You to query JSON data (and other formats) directly from S3 - no loading. Mix and match external S3 data with Redshift data. Performance is excellent.

Docs: docs.aws.amazon.com/redshift/lates…

Customer blog: aws.amazon.com/blogs/big-data…

summary: I'm familiar, and its an amazing service, but I think its overkill for my use case (and many use cases). It requires a RedShift Cluster 24/7, which incurs cost. I really want to have something that is entirely consumption based, otherwise I'd just use RDS + PostgreSQL.

content.html: I'm familiar, and its an amazing service, but I think its overkill for my use case (and many use cases). It requires a RedShift Cluster 24/7, which incurs cost. I really want to have something that is entirely consumption based, otherwise I'd just use RDS + PostgreSQL.
content.value: I'm familiar, and its an amazing service, but I think its overkill for my use case (and many use cases). It requires a RedShift Cluster 24/7, which incurs cost. I really want to have something that is entirely consumption based, otherwise I'd just use RDS + PostgreSQL.

summary: If S3 had a feature to list objects based upon the new-ish object tagging features, that would enable a whole new class of application on top of S3. Essentially a basic object database with object classification/taxonomies.

content.html: If S3 had a feature to list objects based upon the new-ish object tagging features, that would enable a whole new class of application on top of S3. Essentially a basic object database with object classification/taxonomies.
content.value: If S3 had a feature to list objects based upon the new-ish object tagging features, that would enable a whole new class of application on top of S3. Essentially a basic object database with object classification/taxonomies.

summary: You don't have to keep the cluster up 24/7 if you only issue queries at certain times. Clusters come up and down in just a few minutes. External table metadata is stored in Glue catalog, so persists without a cluster. We announced at Re:Invent that we will supported nested data.

content.html: You don't have to keep the cluster up 24/7 if you only issue queries at certain times. Clusters come up and down in just a few minutes. External table metadata is stored in Glue catalog, so persists without a cluster. We announced at Re:Invent that we will supported nested data.
content.value: You don't have to keep the cluster up 24/7 if you only issue queries at certain times. Clusters come up and down in just a few minutes. External table metadata is stored in Glue catalog, so persists without a cluster. We announced at Re:Invent that we will supported nested data.

summary: My use case is to query from a Lambda function that is exposed via API Gateway as an HTTP service to back a CMS. Needs to be always available instantly, which means I'd pretty much have to leave it running.

content.html: My use case is to query from a Lambda function that is exposed via API Gateway as an HTTP service to back a CMS. Needs to be always available instantly, which means I'd pretty much have to leave it running.
content.value: My use case is to query from a Lambda function that is exposed via API Gateway as an HTTP service to back a CMS. Needs to be always available instantly, which means I'd pretty much have to leave it running.
